'''Alvin Youngblood Hart''' (born March 2, 1963, [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[California]], [[United States]])<ref name="musician">[http://www.musicianguide.com/biographies/1608002475/Alvin-Youngblood-Hart.html Musicianguide.com biography - accessed January 2008]</ref> is a [[Grammy Award]]-winning [[United States|American]] [[musician]].

==Career==
Hart was born in Oakland, California, and spent some time in [[Carroll County, Mississippi|Carroll County]], [[Mississippi]], in his youth, where he was influenced by the Mississippi Country Blues performed by his relatives.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 117
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>
Hart is known as one of the world's foremost practitioners of [[country blues]]. He is also known as a faithful torchbearer for the 1960s and 1970s [[guitar]] rock of his [[adolescence|youth]], as well as Western Swing and vintage country. His music has been compared to a list of diverse artists ranging from [[Lead Belly]], [[Spade Cooley]] to [[acoustic guitar|acoustic]] and [[electric guitar]] as well as [[banjo]] and sometimes the [[mandolin]]. Bluesman [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]] once said about Hart: "The boy has got thunder in his hands." Hart himself said, "I guess my big break came when I opened for Taj Mahal for four nights at [[Yoshi's (jazz club)|Yoshi's]]."<ref name="russell"/>

His debut album, ''Big Mama's Door'', came out in 1996.<ref name="russell"/>
In 2003, Hart's [[album]] ''Down in the Alley'' was nominated for a [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album]].<ref name="amg">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p174759/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography - accessed January 2008]</ref> In 2005, Hart received a [[Grammy Award]] for his contribution to ''Beautiful Dreamer - The Songs of [[Stephen Foster]]''.

Hart was featured in the 2003 [[Wim Wenders]] [[film]] ''[[The Soul of a Man]]'', which was featured in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s film series ''[[The Blues (film)|The Blues]]''. Hart was also featured in the documentary ''Last of the Mississippi Jukes''.

Hart appeared in the film ''[[The Great Debaters]]'' in 2007, playing a 1930s juke-joint musician.
